block.p: Voters in Mexico End A Monopoly on Power Election returns showed that Mexican voters handed the opposition presidential candidate Vicente Fox Quesada a substantially more decisive victory over the governing party on Sunday than any poll had predicted. With almost all ballots counted, Mr. Fox had 43 percent, to 36 percent for Francisco Labastida Ochoa, the candidate of the party that has governed Mexico for 71 years. But when the dust settles on the first democratic transition of power in Mexico's history, no major party, including Mr. Fox's center-right party, will control either house of Congress.
Mexicans seemed stunned but excited by Mr. Fox's triumph, and a feeling of empowerment echoed among people of many backgrounds.

The Clinton administration welcomed the outcome, saying it was evidence of the maturing of democratic institutions in Mexico and would set the stage for economic growth.

Rebels Bomb Russian Soldiers Suicide bombers in Chechnya set off a series of truck bombs throughout the breakaway republic late Sunday, killing at least 37 Russian soldiers and wounding 74 in areas supposedly under Russian control.

Austrian Warning to Europe Chancellor Wolfgang Schussel said sanctions imposed by the European Union five months ago to punish the country for letting the far-right Freedom Party into the government would have to be lifted before Austria would clear the way for the 15-member body to admit any new countries. Such admissions require unanimous approval.

In Rome, Pride and Conflict Bishop Jacques Gaillot of France, whose superiors had told him the pope wanted him to withdraw from a seminar that is part of a major gay pride event in Rome this week, said he believed that the church had erred in its treatment of homosexuals. The event, World Pride Roma 2000, is timed to coincide with a Holy Year of the Roman Catholic Church. Vatican opposition has elevated the event into a tense political battleground.

P.L.O. Plan for Statehood Leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization decided in Gaza City that a Palestinian state should be declared by mid-September, whether or not a permanent peace deal had been reached with the Israelis. The move expressed general Palestinian frustration with the peace effort while also locking Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, into a tight, potentially explosive time frame.

Effort to Stem China Migration The I.N.S. commissioner, Doris Meissner, met with Chinese officials in Beijing in hope of gaining a commitment for more help in stemming the flow of illegal immigrants. She said illegal migration by sea had been slowed but was rising by air, with 4,000 illegal immigrants from China expected to be sent back from American airports this year.

Gore Links Drug Makers And G.O.P. to High Costs Vice President Al Gore accused drug makers of ''price-gouging'' and ''special interest schemes'' to keep prices high, as he began a weeklong drive on an issue that has emerged as one of the most potent this election season -- the rising cost of prescription drugs. His speech to an elderly crowd in Missouri also sought to link Gov. George W. Bush and Congressional Republicans to the pharmaceutical industry.

Rape Charges at Annapolis Two star football players at the United States Naval Academy, Cordrea Brittingham and Arion Keith Williams, both 21, were charged with raping a female midshipman at an off-campus party, the police in Anne Arundel County, Md., said.

Gettysburg Tower Comes Down The National Park Service demolished the 307-foot-tall Gettysburg National Tower, a privately owned observation tower for tourists that was long criticized as an eyesore by historians, park officials and battlefield preservationists.

Focus on Test Scores Assailed The leaders of the two national teachers unions denounced the movement to raise academic standards in public schools, saying at their unions' conventions that politicians and educators should focus more on developing challenging curriculum and less on testing students.
C. Stanley Ogilvy A mathematics professor and accomplished yachtsman who wrote books about sailing as well as geometry, he was 87.
Harold Nicholas The younger member of the dazzling tap-dancing Nicholas Brothers, who danced in vaudeville, on Broadway, in nightclubs, on television and in movie musicals, was 79.

9 Officers Face Discipline Over Post-Parade Assaults Police Commissioner Howard Safir said nine New York City police officers, including six supervisors, would be disciplined for mistakes that allowed a mob to convert a section of Central Park into a menacing gantlet in which dozens of women were sexually abused after the National Puerto Rican Day Parade.
Citing Health, Mayor Resigns Edward A. Hanna, the mayor of Utica who has been facing allegations of sexual harassment, announced his resignation.

Snacks Drive Up Movie Costs The cost of a night at the movies for a family of four rose about 3 percent in the last year, to $38.90 from $37.69, a city survey of 78 theaters found. Ticket prices rose only 2 percent, but snack prices jumped 6 percent.

A First in Heart Surgery A 51-year-old patient at the veterans hospital in Pittsburgh recently had coronary artery bypass surgery without general anesthesia; the local anesthesia and sedation left him awake for parts of the operation, which he said was pain-free.

A Distraction From Pain Virtual reality -- immersive, interactive computer graphics -- has helped ease pain in clinical experiments. It is also being used to treat fear of flying or thunderstorms, help diabetics warm their hands and mitigate crippling war memories.
Advancing at Wimbledon Martina Hingis beat Anke Huber, 6-1, 6-2, to reach the quarterfinals, where she will meet Venus Williams.
U.S. Women Win Soccer Cup The United States beat Brazil, 1-0, to claim the Gold Cup, a regional championship on the road to the Summer Olympics.

Saudis Move to Curb Prices Saudi Arabia, the world's largest exporter of crude oil, announced plans to increase production by 500,000 barrels a day. Analysts said the move was unlikely to dampen pump prices for American motorists this summer, but they hoped it would push down prices for heating oil.

Maneuvering in Copyright Case Napster, the embattled Internet music service, asked a federal judge not to shut it down, asserting in a court brief that individual users were doing nothing illegal by making personal collections of copyrighted music downloaded from the Internet.

Joining Microsoft Defense Microsoft added Carter G. Phillips, 47, one of the nation's leading appellate lawyers, to the legal team handling the company's appeal of the federal antitrust ruling against it.

Stocks Up in Light Trading Stocks rose broadly after the first important data of the month, the National Association of Purchasing Management's monthly factory index, showed a lower-than-expected reading for manufacturing activity in June. The Dow gained 112.78 points, or 1.1 percent, to 10,560.67; the Nasdaq rose 25.82 points, to 3,991.93; and the S.& P. 500 climbed 14.72 points, or 1 percent, to 1,469.32.
Editorials: The highest honor; Mexico's democratic breakthrough; Washington reneges on a bargain.
